Introduction

Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is a chronic, immune-mediated esophageal disease characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the esophageal epithelium.  It presents with symptoms related to esophageal dysfunction, such as dysphagia and food impaction.  The prevalence of EoE has been increasing over the past few decades, paralleling the rise in other allergic diseases.

Pathophysiology

EoE is an immune-mediated inflammatory response to specific food and environmental antigens.  On exposure, these antigens activate T-helper 2 lymphocytes, leading to the release of cytokines such as IL-5 and IL-13.  These cytokines promote eosinophil proliferation and recruitment to the esophagus.  Eosinophils release toxic granules that cause tissue damage, leading to the clinical manifestations of EoE.

Risk factors

  • Genetic predisposition:  A family history of EoE or other atopic conditions increases the likelihood of developing the disease.
  • Allergic diseases:  Individuals with asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis, or food allergies are at higher risk for EoE.
  • Gender and age:  EoE is more common in male patients and is often diagnosed in childhood or early adulthood.

Pathology

Histologically, EoE is characterized by significant eosinophilic infiltration, usually with eosinophils >15/hpf in esophageal biopsies (

image 1
).  Additional features include basal cell hyperplasia, subepithelial fibrosis, and the presence of eosinophilic microabscesses.

Clinical presentation

The symptoms of EoE vary with age:

  • Adults (

    ):  Dysphagia, particularly with solid foods, is the most common presentation.  Food impaction, retrosternal chest pain, upper abdominal pain, and reflux-like symptoms unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are also typical.
  • Children (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  Feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, vomiting, and abdominal pain are common presentations.  Toddlers with EoE typically present with feeding dysfunction, which can manifest as failure to progress past liquids/purees or a preference for soft foods after previously tolerating solids.  Limited intake of solid foods may lead to poor weight gain.

Diagnosis

Patients with suggestive manifestations should undergo endoscopic evaluation.  Diagnosis of EoE is based on a combination of clinical, endoscopic, and histopathologic criteria:

  • Clinical evaluation:  Symptoms attributable to esophageal dysfunction (eg, dysphagia, food impaction) are present.  A comorbid history of atopic disorders (eg, asthma, allergic rhinitis, allergic eczema) supports the diagnosis.
  • Endoscopy:  Identifying characteristic features such as esophageal rings (
    image 2
    ) (trachealization), linear furrows, white exudates (plaques), and strictures is helpful.
  • Histopathology:  Biopsy is taken from multiple sites in the esophagus; characteristic findings include an eosinophil-predominant infiltrate, eosinophilic microabscesses, and basal cell hyperplasia.

In patients with reflux-type symptoms, failure to respond to an adequate trial of PPIs may suggest EoE.  However, some patients with EoE experience improvement with PPIs, and EoE and gastroesophageal reflux disease (which usually does respond to PPI therapy) may coexist.  Therefore, a positive or negative response to a PPI trial is not definitive for diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis

  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):  has symptoms such as dysphagia and retrosternal chest pain but typically responds to PPIs and has fewer eosinophils on biopsy.
  • Achalasia:  presents with dysphagia and chest pain but can be distinguished by aperistalsis and esophageal dilation on barium swallow, as well as manometry showing impaired lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.
  • Infectious esophagitis:  esophageal infections (eg, cytomegalovirus [CMV], herpes simplex virus [HSV], Candida) can also cause dysphagia and chest pain.  However, these disorders typically occur in immunocompromised individuals, and endoscopic findings are distinct, which may include fluffy white exudates in Candida esophagitis and esophageal ulcerations in CMV and HSV esophagitis (
    image 3
    ).
  • Medication-induced esophagitis:  is characterized by direct caustic injury to intestinal mucosa.  Common causative medications include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, tetracyclines, and bisphosphonates.  This type of esophagitis typically presents with acute odynophagia and retrosternal pain.  Endoscopy shows discrete ulcerations.
  • Celiac disease:  is characterized by eosinophilic infiltration in the gastrointestinal tract.  It can be differentiated through positive serologic tests and villous atrophy on duodenal biopsy.

Evaluation

Laboratory testing is often performed in patients with dysphagia, but no tests are diagnostic for EoE.  However, some tests may be suggestive, including the following:

  • Allergy testing:  Skin prick tests and serum-specific IgE tests help identify food and environmental allergens that may contribute to EoE.
  • Complete blood count (CBC):  A CBC may reveal peripheral eosinophilia, although this is not specific to EoE.

Imaging is not typically required for diagnosis.  However, supportive findings include the following:

  • Barium swallow may reveal esophageal strictures or narrowing and is useful in assessing motility disorders.
  • Endoscopic ultrasonography can assess esophageal wall thickness and subepithelial fibrosis, although it is not routinely used in EoE diagnosis.

Management

Management of EoE includes dietary, pharmacologic, and endoscopic interventions:

  • Dietary management:  Dietary management includes an elemental diet using amino acidâ€“based formulas, particularly in children, and elimination diets that remove the most common food allergens (eg, milk, wheat, soy, eggs, nuts, seafood).
  • Pharmacologic treatment:
    • Topical corticosteroids, such as swallowed fluticasone or budesonide, are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for reducing inflammation.  Metered-dose inhalers can be cost-effective; the medication is sprayed into the back of the throat and swallowed.
    • PPIs (eg, omeprazole, lansoprazole) may be used empirically to reduce acid-related symptoms and esophageal eosinophilia; although most cases of EoE do not improve, some do, so the low toxicity generally warrants a trial.
  • Endoscopic management:  Esophageal dilation is reserved for patients with significant strictures causing dysphagia.

Complications

  • Esophageal strictures:  These may require repeated dilations to manage narrowing of the esophagus.
  • Food impaction:  This can necessitate emergency endoscopic intervention to remove impacted food.
  • Fibrosis:  Chronic inflammation can lead to permanent structural changes such as fibrosis.
  • Impact on quality of life:  Ongoing symptoms of EoE can significantly affect daily activities and dietary choices, impacting patients' quality of life.

Prognosis

EoE is a chronic condition requiring long-term management.  With appropriate treatment, many patients achieve symptomatic relief and histologic remission.  However, relapse is common with discontinuation of therapy.  Ongoing monitoring and periodic endoscopic evaluations are often necessary to manage the disease effectively.

Summary

Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic inflammatory esophageal disease driven by an immune response to specific allergens.  It presents with symptoms related to esophageal dysfunction and requires a combination of dietary modifications, pharmacologic therapy, and, sometimes, endoscopic interventions for management.  Early recognition and targeted treatment are essential for preventing complications such as strictures and food impaction, thereby improving patient outcomes and quality of life.
